metadata.title: DABCO- and DBU-intercalated α-zirconium phosphate as latent thermal catalysts in the copolymerization of glycidyl phenyl ether (GPE) and hexahydro-4-methylphthalic anhydride (MHHPA)

C (%) H (%) N (%) d (Å) α-ZrP·DABCO-RXN 14.37 3.28 4.85 14.0 α-ZrP·DBU-RXN 36.18 4.07 1.10 23.3 DABCO- and DBU-intercalated α-zirconium phosphate as latent thermal catalysts in the copolymerization of glycidyl phenyl ether (GPE) and hexahydro-4-methylphthalic anhydride (MHHPA) Osamu Shimomura a ⁎ Takatoshi Nishisako a Shunro Yamaguchi b Junko Ichihara b Manabu Kirino c Atsushi Ohtaka a Ryôki Nomura a a Department of Applied Chemistry, Osaka Institute of Technology, 5-16-1 Omiya, Ashahi-ku, Osaka 535-8585, Japan Department of Applied Chemistry Osaka Institute of Technology 5-16-1 Omiya Ashahi-ku Osaka 535-8585 Japan b Institute of Scientific and Industrial Research, Osaka University, 8-1 Mihogaoka, Ibaraki, Osaka 567-0047, Japan Institute of Scientific and Industrial Research Osaka University 8-1 Mihogaoka Ibaraki Osaka 567-0047 Japan c Three Bond Fine Chemical Co., Ltd., 1-1 Oyama-cho, Midori-ku, Sagamihara, Kanagawa 252-0416, Japan Three Bond Fine Chemical Co., Ltd. 1-1 Oyama-cho Midori-ku Sagamihara Kanagawa 252-0416 Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The latent catalytic abilities of tertiary amines-intercalated α-zirconium phosphate [(α-ZrP·amine): 1,4-diazabicyclo[2,2,2]octane (α-ZrP·DABCO) and 1,8-diazabicyclo[5,4,0]undec-7-ene (α-ZrP·DBU)] were examined by copolymerization of glycidyl phenyl ether (GPE) and hexahydro-4-methylphthalic anhydride (MHHPA) at varying temperatures for 1h periods. Polymerization was not observed until the reactants were heated to 100°C or above. Upon increasing the temperature, the conversion factors of GPE increased such that, at 140°C, both conversions were over 90% for α-ZrP·DABCO and α-ZrP·DBU. The thermal stabilities of GPE and MHHPA with the catalysts at 40°C for 144h were tested: GPE with α-ZrP·DBU achieved conversions of 9%. The reaction in the presence of α-ZrP·DABCO did not proceed at 40°C for 144h. Keywords Latent thermal catalyst Intercalation α-Zirconium phosphate DABCO DBU 1 Introduction There has been considerable interest in development of latent polymerization catalysts that are completely inert in the monomer or prepolymer under storage conditions up to 40°C under indoor lighting [1–21]. We have previously reported that primary alkylamines intercalated with α-zirconium phosphate [α-Zr(HPO4)2·H2O, α-ZrP], α-ZrP·Hed (1-aminohexadecane), α-ZrP·Oct (1-aminooctane), α-ZrP·Bu (1-aminobutane) and α-ZrP·Pr (1-aminopropane), can serve as latent thermal initiators in the reaction of glycidyl phenyl ether (GPE) [22]. Among them, the intercalation compound of α-ZrP·Hed showed the potential to initiate the reaction upon heating. While it did not react with GPE at 40°C, increasing the temperature increased the conversion factor such that, at 140°C for 1h, conversion of 64% was obtained. Although we showed the potential of intercalation compounds to function as initiators, molar equivalents of the intercalated primary amines were generally needed to react with the epoxide. In the case of intercalated tertiary amines, catalytic amounts are expected to serve as curing accelerators for epoxy resins. We prepared intercalation compounds of 1,4-diazabicyclo[2,2,2]octane (DABCO) and 1,8-diazabicyclo[5,4,0]undec-7-ene (DBU) with α-ZrP, and examined the catalytic activity of α-ZrP·DABCO and α-ZrP·DBU in the curing of GPE with hexahydro-4-methylphthalic anhydride (MHHPA). In the course of writing this paper, we found a patent on intercalated tertiary amines serving as curing accelerators in epoxy resins. The patent described the products obtained by reacting zirconium phosphate, titanium phosphate, tin phosphate, or Magadiite (H2Si14O29 3H2O) with tertiary amines used as a hardening accelerators, e.g., tris(dimethylaminomethyl) phenol, DBU, imidazole, benzimidazole and 2-ethyl-4-methylimidazole [23]. The storage stabilities of the products were tested by spiral flow tests, namely, the time until spiral flow decreased to 10% of the initial value. The spiral flow test gave satisfactory results for the products after mixing the curing accelerator with novolac-type epoxy resin for 30 days. The abilities of the intercalated amines as latent hardening accelerators were evaluated by measuring the torque after 5min from initiation at 175°C using a curelastometer or by compactibility after storage for 2 weeks at 40°C. Compared to the tertiary amines themselves, the intercalated amines showed faster hardening and better compactibility in addition to better storage stability. However, substantial differences were not found among these intercalated catalysts in the novolac-type epoxy resin curing at 175°C. These tests are not enough to estimate the performance for curing commonly used epoxy resins at lower temperature. Therefore, for the estimation, it is necessary to examine the change at the molecular level. Our present study demonstrated that intercalated catalysts showed good performance and individual behavior regarding latent hardening accelerators for the reaction of GPE with MHHPA. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials α-Zr(HPO4)2·H2O (CZP-100) was purchased from Daiichi Kigenso Kagaku Kogyo Co., Ltd.; DABCO and GPE from Aldrich Chemical Co., Inc.; and DBU and MHHPA from Tokyo Chemical Industries, Co., Ltd., Solvents were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Measurements X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a Rigaku RINT2200 with CuKα radiation over a scan range of 3–40° at a rate of 2°min−1. NMR spectra in solution were recorded on a Varian Unity-300 spectrometer using tetramethylsilane (TMS) as an internal standard. The contents of amine and water in the intercalation compounds of α-ZrP were measured using a Yanaco CHN Corder MT-5. 31P MAS and 13C CPMAS NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance III 600WB NMR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out with a Shimadzu DTG-60 at a heating rate of 10°C/min under nitrogen. Gel permeation chromatographic analyses (GPC) were carried out on a Shodex GPC-101 (LF804×3 and KF-800RF×3, THF as eluent) using polystyrene standards. 2.3 Preparation of DABCO-intercalated α-ZrP (α-ZrP·DABCO) The intercalation of DABCO into the layers of α-Zr(HPO4)2·H2O (α-ZrP) was carried out by slightly modifying a previously reported method [24]. α-ZrP (10.0g) was added to 142mL of a 0.7moldm−3 DABCO aqueous solution. The resulting mixture was then allowed to stand at 40°C for 24h, after which the product was collected by centrifugation and washed with water several times. The resulting residue was dried under vacuum. 2.4 Preparation of DBU-intercalated α-ZrP (α-ZrP·DBU) α-ZrP (5.00g) was added to a solution of DBU (2.53g) in water (33mL). The resulting mixture was stirred at 40°C for 24h, after which the product was collected by centrifugation and washed with water several times. The residue was dried under vacuum. 2.5 Typical polymerization procedure A mixture of GPE (151mg, 1.0mmol), MHHPA (172mg, 1.0mmol) and α-ZrP·DABCO (11.6mg, 0.030 mmol; content of DABCO: 0.016mmol) was heated at 140°C for 1h. A small aliquot of the reaction mixture was dissolved in CDCl3 and its 1H NMR spectra were acquired to determine the extent of conversion of the GPE and MHHPA. The conversion of GPE was measured from the peak area ratio of the aromatic protons at δ 6.9 with the decreasing methylene proton at δ 2.92. The conversion of MHHPA was measured from the peak area ratio of the aromatic protons at δ 6.9 with the increasing methine proton of COOCH2 CH at δ 5.3. 2.6 Polymerization procedure for preparation of poly[GPE-co-MHHPA] with α-ZrP·DABCO A mixture of GPE (7.55g, 50.0mmol), MHHPA (8.40g, 50.0mmol) and α-ZrP·DABCO (584mg, 1.51 mmol; content of DABCO: 0.83mmol) was heated at 140°C for 3h. After the reaction, THF was added to the mixture and the residue was filtered off, rinsed, dried under vacuum, and then submitted for XRD analysis (hereafter, the resulting products abbreviated to α-ZrP·DABCO-RXN). The obtained polymer was isolated by precipitation with methanol and dried under vacuum to give 51% yield. The copolymer was identified as poly[GPE-co-MHHPA] by 1H- and 13C NMR spectral analysis [25]. The number-average molecular weight (Mn) and the molecular weight distribution (Mw/Mn) were found to be 2600 and 1.4, respectively (GPC, calibrated by polystyrene standards). 2.7 Polymerization procedure for preparation of poly[GPE-co-MHHPA] with α-ZrP·DBU A mixture of GPE (1.49g, 9.9mmol), MHHPA (1.67g, 9.9mmol) and α-ZrP·DBU (138mg, 0.30mmol; content of DBU: 0.25mmol) was heated at 120°C for 1h. After addition of THF to the mixture, the insoluble material was filtered off and rinsed to wash the polymer, dried under vacuum and submitted for XRD analysis (hereafter, the resulting products abbreviated to α-ZrP·DBU-RXN). The obtained polymer was isolated in 5.6% yield by precipitation with methanol and drying under vacuum. The copolymer was identified as poly[GPE-co-MHHPA] by 1H NMR spectrum [25]. The number-average molecular weight (Mn) and the molecular weight distribution (Mw/Mn) were found to be 720 and 1.2, respectively (GPC, calibrated by polystyrene standards). 3 Results and discussion The basal distances and compositions as estimated from XRD and CHN elemental analyses, respectively, of the prepared intercalation compounds are summarized in Table 1 [26]. Intercalation compounds of DABCO and DBU with α-ZrP at a ratio of 0.56 and 0.83 per 1mol of the phosphate compound were prepared. The basal distances of 16.1Å (2θ =5.5°), 14.4Å (2θ =6.2), and 10.9Å (2θ =8.1) for α-ZrP·DABCO and 20.0Å (2θ =4.4°) and 13.7Å (2θ =6.4) for α-ZrP·DBU expanded from that of pristine α-ZrP (7.6Å, 2θ =11.7°). The XRD patterns suggested that several phases may exist in both intercalated compounds. These basal distances were longer than those of the corresponding diamine intercalation compounds, e.g., 1,2-diaminoethane (11.0Å) and 1,4-diaminobutane (13.3Å). The diamines were uptaken with the ratio of 1.0 per 1mol of phosphate compound in α-ZrP [27]. In both title intercalated compounds, empty spaces for GPE and/or MHHPA in the interlayer might exist because of their longer basal distances and smaller uptake ratios. The thermal properties of these α-ZrP-amine intercalation compounds were examined by TG-DTA as shown in Fig. 1 . α-ZrP·DABCO gradually lost H2O up to 200°C (6.1% of weight loss) and the weight decreased until 600°C. In TGA and DTA curves of α-ZrP·DBU, H2O was lost up to 200°C (6.1% of weight loss) and the weight gradually decreased until 600°C. Assuming that the weight loss from 200°C to 450°C was attributed to that of DABCO or DBU, each of the compositional formula was calculated. α-ZrP·DABCO; α-Zr(HPO4)2(C6H12N2)0.50·1.2H2O, and α-ZrP·DBU; α-Zr(HPO4)2(C9H16N2)0.60·1.3H2O. The lower contents of DABCO and DBU and the lower contents of H2O were calculated based on the weight loss in the assumed temperature ranges. Dehydration and deintercalation might occur under and/or over the ranges. The reaction of GPE with MHHPA using the α-ZrP·DABCO and α-ZrP·DBU intercalation compounds as latent catalysts (at a level of 3 mol% of the Zr for GPE) was then examined at varying temperatures for 1h periods by 1H NMR spectroscopy as described in Section 2 (Scheme 1 ) [28]. Fig. 2 shows the conversion of GPE in the presence of α-ZrP·DABCO and α-ZrP·DBU intercalation compounds. In both cases, the GPE did not change below 80°C. In the case of α-ZrP·DBU, the reaction proceeded at 100°C with 35% conversion. In contrast, the conversion in the presence of α-ZrP·DABCO was merely 8% at 100°C. Upon increasing the temperature to 140°C, the conversion factors increased such that conversions of 90% for α-ZrP·DABCO and 94% for α-ZrP·DBU were obtained [29]. The conversions of MHHPA shown in Fig. 3 were in good agreement with those of GPE. The thermal stabilities of the α-ZrP-amine intercalation compounds as latent catalysts were evaluated by following the GPE conversion at 40°C for 144h (6 days). As shown in Fig. 4 , GPEs with α-ZrP·DBU for 144h achieved conversions of 9%, while the reaction in the presence of α-ZrP·DABCO did not proceed at all. For comparison, the reaction of GPE—MHHPA with the amines of DABCO and DBU (at a level of 3mol% for GPE) at 40°C for 96h gave 59% (DABCO) and 77% (DBU) conversions, respectively. Thus, the thermal latency of the amines intercalated into α-ZrP in both cases was demonstrated, with the α-ZrP·DABCO intercalation compound showing better thermal stability than α-ZrP·DBU. The molecular weight and molecular weight distribution of poly[GPE-co-MHHPA] initiated with α-ZrP·DABCO and α-ZrP·DBU were determined by GPC as Mn =2600 and Mw/Mn =1.4 for α-ZrP·DABCO at 140°C for 3h and Mn =720 and Mw/Mn =1.2 for α-ZrP·DBU at 120°C for 1h. The basal distances of intercalation compounds of α-ZrP·DABCO and α-ZrP·DABCO-RXN are shown in Fig. 5 (b) and (c). After the reaction, the basal distance was shortened from 16.1Å to 14.0Å. The XRD patterns of α-ZrP·DBU and α-ZrP·DBU-RXN are shown in Fig. 5(d) and (e). Here, the longest basal distances were expanded from 20.0Å to 23.3Å. 31P MAS NMR spectra of α-ZrP·DABCO and α-ZrP·DABCO-RXN are shown in Fig. 6 (a) and (b). The main single peak of both α-ZrP·DABCO and α-ZrP·DABCO-RXN is observed at a δ value of −22.2, which corresponded to protonated phosphate group: HPO4 2−. The chemical shift suggested that interaction between DABCO and HPO4 group was not strong compared with that between alkylamines and HPO4 group [22]. As shown in Fig. 7 , there were also no substantial differences in the 13C CPMAS NMR spectra of α-ZrP·DABCO and α-ZrP·DABCO-RXN. From the N content from elemental analysis shown in Table 2 , less than 10% of intercalated DABCO was deintercalated, which caused the shortening the basal distance from 16.1Å to 14.0Å. 31P MAS NMR spectra of α-ZrP·DBU and α-ZrP·DBU-RXN are shown in Fig. 8 (a) and (b). The main peaks of α-ZrP·DBU are observed at δ −20.8 and −23.9, and after the reaction, the main single peak of α-ZrP·DBU is observed at δ −23.6. These signals correspond to protonated phosphate group: HPO4 2− [30]. The 13C CPMAS NMR spectra of α-ZrP·DBU and α-ZrP·DBU-RXN are presented in Fig. 9(a’) and (b’). Fig. 9 (b’) shows the aromatic carbons associated with the GPE at δ 157.1, 127.1, 118.0 and 113.0, as well as the C of the structural main chain methylene groups at δ 67.2 and the carbonyl groups at δ 180–165. After the reaction, the carbon content of α-ZrP·DBU increased from 19.54% to 36.18% as shown in Table 2. From these results, the reaction products exist in the interlayer of α-ZrP·DBU and at most 20% of DBU remained in the layer as illustrated in Fig. 10 . When considerable amounts of intercalated amines are discharged from the interlayer, polymerized products would be formed in the layers. The presence of the products in the interlayer give rise to the expansion of the basal distance from 20.0Å to 23.3Å. In the case of using α-ZrP·DABCO, a small part of the deintercalated DABCO catalyzed the polymerization over 100°C and at 140°C gave a polymer with Mn =2600. As most of the DABCO still existed in the interlayer, the deintercalated DABCO catalyzed the reaction effectively. On the other hand, most of the intercalated DBU was deintercalated and catalyzed the polymerization at 120°C to give a polymer with Mn =720 and the products remained in the interlayer. In this process, DBU was deintercalated and catalyzed the reaction to give products with larger molecular size than the reactants. As the resulting products were not basic, the products with larger molecular size would not infiltrate the interlayer. The reactants would get in the vacant space after the deintercalation and would react in the interlayer. The resulting zirconium phosphate containing polymer may serve as a filler material with unique connections between the polymer of the interlayer and the polymer outside the inorganic materials. 4 Conclusion The catalytic performance of α-ZrP·DABCO and α-ZrP·DBU in the copolymerization of GPE and MHHPA was examined. α-ZrP·DABCO did not catalyze the reaction of GPE with MHHPA at 40°C for 144h, but did catalyze the reaction over 100°C and gave a polymer with 90% conversion of GPE at 140°C. α-ZrP·DBU catalyzed the polymerization at 100°C or above and gave a polymer with 94% conversion of GPE at 140°C. Although these catalysts showed individual behavior in the reaction of GPE and MHHPA, these intercalated compounds possessed storage stability and served as latent polymerization catalysts. It is noteworthy that after the polymerization in the presence of α-ZrP·DBU the resulting products existed between the interlayers. Thus, α-ZrP·DBU not only serves as latent catalyst and but also is expected to serve as filler for reinforced composite. Acknowledgments This work was performed under the Cooperative Research Program of “Network Joint Research Center for Materials and Devices”. We wish to thank A Rabbit Science Japan Co., Ltd., for CHN elemental analyses. We also thank Dr. M. Shizuma and Dr. S. Kawano of Osaka Municipal Technical Research Institute for GPC analyses. coredata.dc:description: The latent catalytic abilities of tertiary amines-intercalated α-zirconium phosphate [(α-ZrP·amine): 1,4-diazabicyclo[2,2,2]octane (α-ZrP·DABCO) and 1,8-diazabicyclo[5,4,0]undec-7-ene (α-ZrP·DBU)] were examined by copolymerization of glycidyl phenyl ether (GPE) and hexahydro-4-methylphthalic anhydride (MHHPA) at varying temperatures for 1h periods. Polymerization was not observed until the reactants were heated to 100°C or above. Upon increasing the temperature, the conversion factors of GPE increased such that, at 140°C, both conversions were over 90% for α-ZrP·DABCO and α-ZrP·DBU. The thermal stabilities of GPE and MHHPA with the catalysts at 40°C for 144h were tested: GPE with α-ZrP·DBU achieved conversions of 9%. The reaction in the presence of α-ZrP·DABCO did not proceed at 40°C for 144h.
